reviews.review_text: I can say i really dig this game.

Awesome little game that's suitable for both short and long periods of gaming. Prefer getting the free version to the paid one as I only have to pay to unlock the bits I'd actually use. Word of warning: trying to install this on my Ubuntu partition just didn't work and the devs don't seem to want to fix it. If you want to play this, you pretty much have to have Windows.

This game may be small, but mighty. As this game is only single-player, you can have the peace and tranquility of yourself relaxing. It's a somewhat quiet game, so you can ready your dwarves, level 'em up, and lean back and WATCH THEM GO! I've spent some time playing, and I recommend those who do not mind waiting and patience. But even if you ARE one of those people who need short time, go on 5 minute arcade! This game is very fun and a little addicting, so I guess I would recommend this.

Very fun, addictive, and quite silly all things considered. Great little game, though the arrows mechanic is a little odd and needs getting used to. Overall, give it a try. It's free, fun and silly. :)

While I do recommend 'Dwarfs!' as a great time waster, I don't recommend it as a serious investment. This kind of game is really for the more casual gamer. I find it to be a great way to relax and take a break from more challenging or competitive games. It is entertaining, but only addictive to a point. Some of the features that you can purchase are more costly that some bargain bin games, but I don't know what they are like.

I've logged about 12 hours on this game so far and I've so far only purchased the endless mode DLC, so about twelve games. Maybe more. Dwarfs is a free to play strategy arcade game in which the player takes the place of an omnipotent god/guide/being/etc. The player guides the dwarves that start underground in a cave in an attempt to get a high score by doing things like defeating enemies, digging minerals, and so on.  If you want the short version of this review: If you like strategy, and you want something you can play in the off time, get this game. It's free, it's fun, and perfect for a 'Lunch time game'. If you want to get more out of the game once you buy it, I highly recommend you get the Endless mode DLC. If you want a little bit more in depth, here goes.  VISUAL AESTHETICS:  The game looks very good, and a lot of love and personal style went into creating everything. The dwarves in particular are very adorable to me, and everything oozes with character. Something worth mentioning as well is how well the visuals coincide with the gameplay, in that extra efforts were taken to ensure that the player was not lost or confused at any point, though there are still sometimes where it gets very easy to get lost in the deep caverns. All in all, the game isn't next-gen and people who are even looking at this shouldn't be expecting groundbreaking graphics. It's cute, adorable, varied, and knit together well with the gameplay with a fantastic style.  SOUND AND MUSIC:  There are a few songs on the soundtrack from this game and they're all very relaxing and gives the game a very zen feeling, most of the time (When lava/water/boss fights break out, it's kinda like running out of air in Sonic...) But the music is fantastic otherwise. It's very well paced with the gameplay, and it never feels like it tries to portray something its not, like some games have. The sound effects aren't very special, some fighting, some clattering. I think one aspect that shines though is the voice of the Dwarves themselves, they're very cute and add to the charm of the game. I think if one played this game repeatedly for hours, the music might get tiresome, but it shouldn't if you play it with moderation.  GAMEPLAY:  So, the big one. How does it play? Pretty damn well. The player has a pool of gold to start with, and the Dwarves dig automatically in random and unpredictable directions. Every wall they dig generates a small amount of gold, and can dig up minerals to get more gold. The player can click and drag a line to a destination on a dwarf (or strategically lay it out on his path) and he will follow that line until it ends, digging whatever lies in his wake, but this costs a small amount of gold. This priority makes controlling the dwarves fantastically fun, and easy. Where does the challenge come from? This game is by no stretch of the imagination easy, even on easy mode. The challenges come in three basic forms. Lava, Water, and 'What lurks in the Darkness when you dig too deep.' Basically, every game you initiate will always have caverns inside, their contents being unrevealed until you choose to dig into them. The three things I just mentioned above will literally pour out, and if they flood your starting location, that's game over. But the player is given the tools to dispose of these problems, which cost money from your gold pool, but for this review I won't go in depth on. As your cave gets bigger and bigger, managing these problems gets tougher and tougher. The player needs to make tactical decisions made primarily on luck ('Does that cave have baddies? Or lava? Nonono, ♥♥♥♥ that, seal that ♥♥♥♥.') or split second reactions because their dwarves tunneled into a cavern full of lava and ends up leaking it through a bunch of tunnels.  Every order in the game is given, but no result is immediate, it's similar to Dungeon Keeper or Evil Genius in that regard, combine this with the aspect of you can't liberally pause time like you can in a game like Dwarf Fortress or Crusader Kings II, this becomes extremely difficult, and that's where most of the challenge comes from (You can however speed up time which just helps the game along and increases its user friendly nature!). From there, it gets more difficult when you start unearthing the boss fights, Goblin Shamans, Spider Queens, and the dreaded Lich Lords. With even harder difficulties, and a bunch of scenarios to boot and DLC if you so desire, the gameplay is fun and inviting. In the base game, you can set your timer for as little as five (5) minutes all the way up to sixty (60) minutes. Despite the strategy involved, this makes the game absolutely perfect in terms of time management. You can pop on for a quick 15 minute game and be done before the kettle boils or its time to go to work. All in all the gameplay makes Dwarfs excellent.  AFFORDABILITY:  This game is free. Not much else I should say there. The only thing you should really buy for this if you want a great time is the endless mode DLC, which is 2 bucks. If you want to fully support the devs, every DLC costs 18 dollars in total. It's great, afforable, and fun. If you like strategy games, you have no reason not to install this game, and buy the endless mode DLC.  REPLAYABILITY:  This is arguably Dwarfs strongest suit. I've yet to get tired of this game, I love it and every game is enjoyable and different. For those of you that want high scores for leaderboards and such, that is available to you. I personally don't enjoy them, but the score in this case is still used fantastically to measure your performance, edging you to just give it one more shot, in a fashion similar to tetris. The caves are randomly generated, the scores are limitless, and the Dwarves do not stop. Keep digging on and on, and see how good you can get.  CONS AND CRITIQUE:  This is a great game, but every great game has a flaw or two. My main complaint is with the end game, where you need to be able to bounce between places in a flash, you can navigate to problems pretty easily the first time, but after that you need to remember where they are. I once lost an extremely good run because a Lich Phantom I forgot about destroyed my base. This could've been very easily been remedied with the incorporation of a mini-map. There's also a few minor complaints I had where there's no way to repair the base or the outposts, which I can kinda understand why and these are meant (usually) to be disposable games, but in Endless Mode at least, I felt like that should've been a feature. Those are really my only complaints about this game.  OVERALL:  If you like Dwarves, get this game. If you like Dwarf Fortress, get this game. If you like strategy games, get this game. If you want a game you can play whilst eating a bowl of cereal in the morning get this game. This is definitely one of my favourite arcade style games to have come out in a while, and I encourage anyone who meets the criteria I listed to get this game. And if you don't meet the criteria, I ask that you at least give it a shot. It's a small download, and a 15 minute game certainly wouldn't hurt. The tutorial is user friendly, or you can just dive right in. In five words Dwarfs is:  Arcadey and Amusing Digging Adventures.  Thanks for Reading.

This is a game for people who think fast and act faster. The player does not have complete control over the dwarfs mining; you may guide some of their actions but ultimately you will have too many of them to guide every single one and then they'll dig in whatever direction they want. Your job is to guide them to gems and precious metals and see to it that they don't dig into caves with lava or water, thus flooding the cave and killing all dwarfs. To avoid floods, you have to block or blow holes in the ground. This, however, comes at a cost and thus is one of the reasons to why you have to find gems and precious metals early in the game.  The game's graphics has an old look to them, with a horrendously old-fashioned main menu design, which put me off at first. However, while playing the game the design is not bad and has a more 'retro' feel to it. I rather liked the different maps and tutorials. The game seriously tested my patience, though, and I did not enjoy playing under constant pressure.

A major annoyance is that using the words 'F2P' is an understatement, this game is techincally not 'F2P' but rather a 'Free-to-play.....in order to get more modes unlock'   'Yo! Dawg, i heard you like Free to play. So we will put pay walls in your free-to-play game in order to unlock the other modes in a Free-to-play game'.  Do i recommend it. No,  Pros: - Dwarves - Dwarves - Dwarves - Achievements  Cons: -Magicial Shooting geysers - Micro-transcation for other modes to be unlock (yes, including the other diffculites because after all they will be after evey inch of your wallet). - Average AI.  - No innovation. A generic arcade game.   5/10  It's a decent game however without the lack of innovation, and 'locking' the other modes and other diffculties through paywalls. It makes this game an almost eye sore. While masking itself as a 'Fun game'
